Award.AwardTitle: Towards Scientific Understanding of Advanced Transforming Metals

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research is about the bottom-up development of advanced lubricant coatings that are inspired by natural lubricating systems. Specifically, the project will develop new poly(ionic liquid) coatings and investigate their rolling and sliding frictional properties in contact with a swelling ionic liquid solvent. This system offers charged, comb-like polymer chains within a bound/mobile medium, much like natural lubricants, and a liquid with tailorable viscosity and swelling properties to fine tune the tribological performance. The approach of the research will be to employ surface-initiated ring opening metathesis polymerization to grow the lubricant coatings from both planar silicon (oxide) surfaces and silica microparticles. This method enables rapid polymer growth and the ability to tailor the ionic liquid side chain length, composition, and counter ion to investigate molecular-scale effects on the lubricating performance of the coatings. The most promising lubrication systems, based on sliding results, will be employed for the rolling lubrication of silica microspheres confined in both microchannels and hemispherical polymeric cavities.

If successful, this research will lead to new types of lubricated systems improving sliding and rolling lubrication systems. This will lead to greatly reduced friction and wear in microfabricated systems. Outreach will include the development of case studies from this research that will impact undergraduate classes, undergraduate research, and a week-long specialty course for gifted eight graders through the Vanderbilt Summer Academy. Students will learn to assemble coatings, measure their surface and tribological properties and connect these properties to basic intermolecular interactions. The research will also create a better understanding in high school by allowing a local high school teacher to participate in this research through a Research Experience for Teachers program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Broad Impacts

Metallic materials undergo permanent deformation under external loading if the loading levels are high. The external loading is often cyclic (ie. varies with time),  the material will undergo fatigue and break. Examples of fatigue are encountered in civil and aerospace structures and mechanical components.  It is possible to minimize the permanent (plastic) deformation by devising special materials that exhibit reversible deformations (rubber like behavior). The Fe-Al and Fe-Ga alloys studied in this project fall into such category.Theory and software emanating from the research can be incorporated into commercial codes for simulations in engineering. This will enhance the analysis  and design capability at an early stage and improve the designs for the benefit of public welfare. 

Intellectual Merit

 The major goal of the project is to study the 'reversible slip' in metallic alloys utilizing Fe-Ga, Fe-Ga-B and Fe-Al alloys. The reversible slip results in recovery of the plastic strains  upon unloading  and the material exhibits ‘rubber like’ or ‘pseudoelastic’ behavior. The role of the boron addition is to elevate the strength and modify the to- and fro- motion behavior of dislocations (defects that are responsible for plastic flow) allowing design of new ‘recoverable’ alloys. In this work, we study the role of boron on the FeGa behavior and  also study FeAl alloys which hold considerable promise.  The specimens are either in single crystalline or polycrystalline form. The use of single crystals facilitates the determination of slip or twin planes and also determination of critical resolved shear stress from experiments to compare theory and experiment. Our experiments used specialized digital image correlation methods which give the local displacement fields.  The sudden change in the displacement gradients is indicative of the onset of slip or yielding in metals. Through experiments and modeling we were able to show reversible slip in such alloys which could result in enhancement in fatigue and fracture resistance. In metallic materials the assumption is made that yielding (or slip) will occur at a characteristic shear stress. On the other hand in FeAl alloys, sucha characteristic shear stress does not exist. Consequently, we showed that the slip behavior is very orientation dependent and also depends on tension versus compression. Our modeling efforts are geared towards predicting the critical shear stress levels at the onset of slip and its dependence on orientation.
